compliant.legal provisions: Data controllers shall take appropriate measures to provide any information referred to in Articles 13 and 14 and any communication under Articles 15 to 22 and 34 relating to processing to the data subject in a concise, transparent, intelligible and easily accessible form, using clear and plain language, in particular for any information addressed specifically to a child. The information shall be provided in writing, or by other means, including, where appropriate, by electronic means. When requested by the data subject, the information may be provided orally, provided that the identity of the data subject is proven by other means.

The information shall be provided in writing, or by other means, including, where appropriate, by electronic means. When requested by the data subject, the information may be provided orally, provided that the identity of the data subject is proven by other means.

Where processing is based on consent pursuant to point (a) of Article 6(1), or point (a) of Article 9(2), the controller shall be able to demonstrate that the data subject has consented to processing of his or her personal data.

non_compliant.legal provisions: The controller shall provide the data subject with the following information: (a) the purposes of the processing for which the personal data are intended as well as the legal basis for the processing; (c) the recipients or categories of recipient to whom the personal data have been or will be disclosed;  2. In addition to the information referred to in paragraph 1, the controller shall, at the time when personal data are obtained, provide the data subject with the following further information necessary to ensure fair and transparent processing: (a) the period for which the personal data will be stored, or if that is not possible, the criteria used to determine that period;
non_compliant.amend: This section needs to clearly state the specific purposes for processing personal data, the legal basis for each purpose (e.g., consent, contract performance, legal obligation, legitimate interest), the categories of recipients of the data (e.g., specific service providers, authorities), and the data retention period or criteria for determining it.

non_compliant.legal provisions: 1. Processing shall be lawful only if and to the extent that at least one of the following applies: (a) the data subject has given consent to the processing of his or her personal data for one or more specific purposes;  2. In addition to the information referred to in paragraph 1, the controller shall, at the time when personal data are obtained, provide the data subject with the following further information necessary to ensure fair and transparent processing: (d) the existence of the right to request from the controller access to and rectification or erasure of personal data or restriction of processing concerning the data subject or to object to processing as well as the right to data portability;
non_compliant.amend: While this question addresses the right to refuse, it needs to explicitly state the legal basis for processing (e.g., consent, contract) and clarify that refusal might be possible if processing is based on consent but may have consequences if processing is necessary for contractual or legal reasons.

non_compliant.legal provisions: 2. The controller shall facilitate the exercise of data subject rights under Articles 15 to 22. In the cases referred to in Article 11(2) and Article 22(3) and (4), the controller shall not refuse to act on the request of the data subject for exercising his or her rights under Articles 15 to 22, unless the controller demonstrates that it is not in a position to identify the data subject. Articles 15-22 outline the data subject's rights, including: - Right of access to personal data (Article 15) - Right to rectification (Article 16) - Right to erasure ('right to be forgotten') (Article 17) - Right to restriction of processing (Article 18) - Right to data portability (Article 20) - Right to object (Article 21)
non_compliant.amend: This section should clearly list all data subject rights under the GDPR, including: - Right of access - Right to rectification - Right to erasure ('right to be forgotten') - Right to restriction of processing - Right to data portability - Right to object - Right to withdraw consent (if applicable) - Right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority

non_compliant.legal provisions: The controller shall provide the data subject with the following information: (b) the identity and the contact details of the controller and, where applicable, of the controller's representative; 2. In addition to the information referred to in paragraph 1, the controller shall, at the time when personal data are obtained, provide the data subject with the following further information necessary to ensure fair and transparent processing: (f) the right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority;
non_compliant.amend: This section should provide clear and specific contact details for the data protection officer (DPO) or other relevant contact point for data subject requests. It should also explicitly mention the data subject's right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority, including the contact details of the relevant authority.

non_compliant.legal provisions: 'consent' of the data subject means any freely given, specific, informed and unambiguous indication of the data subject's wishes by which he or she, by a statement or by a clear affirmative action, signifies agreement to the processing of personal data relating to him or her; 4. Where processing is based on consent pursuant to point (a) of Article 6(1), or point (a) of Article 9(2), the controller shall be able to demonstrate that the data subject has consented to processing of his or her personal data.
non_compliant.amend: The language used for obtaining consent for cookies needs to be more explicit and unambiguous. Simply continuing to browse the website does not constitute valid consent under the GDPR. The website should provide a clear and specific mechanism for users to consent to the use of cookies, such as a checkbox that is not pre-ticked. The cookie banner should also clearly distinguish between essential cookies (necessary for the website's functionality) and non-essential cookies (used for analytics, advertising, etc.). Users should have the option to accept or reject non-essential cookies.
